docs.lead_paragraph: Overview | What are the implications of a new study showing that kids use electronic devices virtually all the time? In this lesson, students take a close look at their own media use over time, identify any detrimental habits, then develop personal plans and put them into action. They then write and deliver persuasive speeches on the media and technology topic of their choice.

headline.main: Every Waking Minute? Examining Personal Media Habits

docs.abstract: Lesson Plan | Gauging and reflecting on personal use of electronic devices and media, then developing and trying plans of action to change detrimental habits.
docs.snippet: Lesson Plan | Gauging and reflecting on personal use of electronic devices and media, then developing and trying plans of action to change detrimental habits.

byline.original: By SHANNON DOYNE and HOLLY EPSTEIN OJALVO

docs.lead_paragraph: As fashionistas know, the designer and yoga devotee Donna Karan infuses serenity in her clothes. Calm can also be found in her Balinese beanbag chairs, teak tables and at a workshop this Saturday at Donna Karan’s Urban Zen Center. From 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., Dr. James Gordon will lead a program titled “Unstuck: Practical Steps Toward Clarity and Delight” to help urbanites find balance in their busy city lives. He’ll focus on techniques like mediation, guided imagery, movement, dance and nutrition, as well as experiments with drawing and dialogue. He hopes participants will “leave with a new perspective on and appreciation of ourselves.” Ommm.
